Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 03:30PM Zippychick wrote: Annie: I may be all wrong about this, but it seems that I read somewhere that Xeloda escapes the body through the tiny vessels in our hands and feet.  I think there is a difference between tenderness from peeling and cracking and the constant pressure of being on our feet. My feet are so calloused and thick skinned that I believe my slight pain comes from the pressure of being on my feet.  I think if we walked around on our hands we would experience this same sensation.  In other words I think there are two different types of pain associated with the hand/foot syndrome. zippychick

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 05:20AM Zippychick wrote: I am a xelodian.  LOL! I am on my first cycle of xeloda, in fact this is my first week off.  I take 4-500 mg in the am and 4-500 mg in the pm, two weeks on and one week off. This is the maximum dosage for my height and weight.  The only changes that I have noticed so far is a slight pinkness on my feet and hands and a slight tenderness when I walk around in my sockfeet.  So I make it a point to wear my cushy house slippers. I have been using the udderly smooth cream from the get go, as my skin is very dry from my previous chemo Taxol/Gemzar. I can't do socks at night because my feet get hot and I understand that we don't want heat on our hands and feet.  I also take Vitamin B6 (150 mg daily).  I make it a point to have 12 hours pass before my evening dose. This is sometimes hard to do, but I was told by other xelodians that this seems to decrease side effects.  I'm holding my breath to see what is going to happen after several cycles, but I understand that when side effects begin to worsen that your Onc. can lower your dosage and the xeloda can be just as effective. Good luck on this drug.  I have heard of many women having years on this drug and even obtaining the status of NED or stable.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 10:38AM Zippychick wrote: Sue: I am on 4000 per day of Xeloda.  I am on my second round and feeling very fatigued but I am slightly anemic.  My Oncologist said it was probably just the Xeloda.  My heels are beginning to hurt when I walk. My feet are red and hot but no peeling or cracking yet.  My hands are just slightly red and it seems to come and go with my hands.  I seldom hear of people being on as high of a dosage as we are but I am hoping that my Oncologist is just using it as a starting dose and that he will decrease the dosage when/if I get too uncomfortable. Let me know how it continues for you. zip
